replies: (To also be fair, sometimes committee hearings overlap and you have to choose which one you‚Äôre going to. Happened to me earlier today - had to leave this hearing earlier so I could ask questions on Oversight about the opioid crisis)

Legit question: As a physician who prescribes opioids for pain all the time, I want to know if anyone in government acknowledges that a huge part of the "crisis" is that people with legitimate pain are having difficulty getting the meds they need.

I have countless patients who wouldn‚Äôt be able to live, function, and go about their lives if it weren‚Äôt for their pain medications. But those people never seem to make it in front of media cameras.
I mean no disrespect, but this is what happens when legislators who know nothing about medicine in general and pain management specifically are trying to fix problems they don't understand.
As a physician, what are your thoughts on medical marijuana? Would you consider prescribing medical marijuana over opioids?

My thoughts exactly! I'm in Canada where it is legal everywhere and am considering MM for an arthritic hip. But most medical doctors don't have a clue about strains, dosage, etc. My doctor looked at me like I had 2 heads.
pretty fly for a trans guy

I use MM for chronic pain, anxiety, and PTSD, and I'd be happy to point you to some helpful resources, if you'd like. One website that helps me a ton is  http://www.leafly.com¬†. Lots of info, including info about Canada's new laws and regulations, but also strains, dosing, etc.

List over to this office. He cut me off of 2mg (I was on 3mg prior and dropped 1mg myself) without a taper which could have killed me.  I was in distress for a couple months until I was finally ok this past January. These doctors today are so worried and the DEA needs to lay off
